content.webTitle: Why do so many film posters have American spellings?

fields.headline: Why do so many film posters have American spellings?
fields.bodyText: First they knock our NHS, then they mess with our film posters; truly, there are days when it's hard not to believe that America hasn't launched a stealth war against us, and that by this time next year we'll have become a fully air-conditioned outcrop of the American Empire, with Cheetos on tap and Meat Loaf on the stereo. The latest attack involves the promotional campaign for The Time Traveler's Wife, the big-screen adaptation of Audrey Niffenegger's novel of the same name. Your eyes do not deceive you: they have indeed spelled it Traveler, as opposed to Traveller. This is not the first time that the spelling of a Hollywood film title has been retained for UK audiences – some of you may recall that in 1986, Martin Scorsese released The Color of Money. This was followed in 1989 by Woody Allen's Crimes and Misdemeanors and Neil LaBute's Your Friends and Neighbors in 1998. Others may take issue with 2001's Pearl Harbor. "It was the same with Journey to the Center of the Earth, which came out last year. It's because that's on all the artwork. We always just keep that, so anything that's got an American spelling stays," says an unrepentant spokesman for the distributors of The Time Traveler's Wife.
